evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 is consistently observable and documented in the hist_dynamic_und_t2_interim dataset.

The hist_dynamic_und_t2_interim dataset corresponds to the provided history items
defeaters: If evidence showed consistent, effective communication and coordination without breakdown
If procedural deviations rather than communication failures better explained the events

The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP marking was obscured or inadequate, or if the blast fence was closer than stated, this would challenge the robustness claim.
If communication or procedural signals were proven effective and the incident still occurred, environmental deficiency might be implicated.

children_spec.statement: Relevant environmental data (e.g., weather, lighting) was available to the flight crew during the incident

node.statement: Communication systems providing environmental or marking information were operational and accessible to the flight crew

assumptions: Availability and accessibility imply effective use and reception of communication and marking information by the flight crew.
The headset operator and wingman roles are part of the communication system considered.
defeaters: If evidence showed that communication systems or environmental markings were physically unavailable or non-operational to the crew.
If there were reports of equipment failure or inaccessibility preventing crew use.

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8 and H9 indicate that communication systems and marking information were known and available to the crew, but procedural non-compliance and lack of effective warnings led to the incident, contradicting the claim that communication systems were operational and accessible.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether communication system availability equates to effective operational use and accessibility by crew.

node.statement: Crew members are available and attentive to communication channels without distractions or incapacitation

defeaters: If evidence showed active, effective communication and timely warnings from crew members preventing the incident.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.

He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. outcome.uncertainty_source: absence of direct mechanical fault evidence; ambiguity in whether control failure occurred

defeaters: If evidence showed lack of training or unavailability of trained personnel during the pushback, or if communication failures were documented that better explain the deviation.

node.statement: Availability of updated pushback procedure documentation to ground crew

assumptions: Training and awareness of TRP imply availability of updated pushback procedure documentation to ground crew.
Lack of warning from wingman or headset operator does not imply absence of procedure documentation but rather procedural deviation.
defeaters: If evidence showed that the ground crew were unaware of updated pushback procedures or that the TRP markings were inadequate or unclear, this would change the assessment.
If communication or coordination failures were documented as primary causes, this would affect the conclusion.

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8 and H9 directly indicate that the trainee driver was trained and aware of the TRP and that the visual signaling method was insufficient, supporting that updated pushback procedure documentation was available and known to ground crew, consistent with procedural deviation rather than environmental marking deficiency.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit documentation excerpts of the updated pushback procedure are provided; inference is based on training and awareness statements.

node.statement: Relevant environmental data (e.g., weather, lighting) was available to the flight crew during the incident

assumptions: Crew awareness of TRP implies availability of relevant environmental data
No evidence indicates environmental data was unavailable or obscured
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP or other environmental markings were obscured or unavailable to the crew
If crew statements indicated lack of awareness or inability to perceive environmental data

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 confirms the presence and visibility of the TRP environmental marking; H9 confirms crew awareness of the TRP; H8 indicates communication and visual signals were used but may have been insufficient, supporting that relevant environmental data was available to the crew.

node.statement: Marking information (e.g., runway/taxiway markings, signage) was present and visible to the flight crew during the incident

assumptions: Markings at the TRP were visible and adequate as per H7.
No direct evidence states markings were not visible to the flight crew.
defeaters: If evidence showed markings were obscured or not visible to the crew, or if the crew explicitly reported inability to see markings, this would change the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 and H7 show the TRP marking was present and defined, but the aircraft passed it and collided with the blast barrier, indicating markings were visible but not heeded. H8 indicates communication and procedural issues rather than marking visibility. This supports procedural deviation over marking deficiency.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether markings were fully visible to the crew or if other factors caused the incident

children_spec.statement: Availability of updated pushback procedure documentation to ground crew
children_spec.test_procedure: Check if the latest pushback procedure documents were distributed and accessible to the ground crew before the operation

children_spec.statement: Availability of functional communication equipment between cockpit and ground crew during pushback
children_spec.test_procedure: Verify if communication devices were operational and used during the pushback process

children_spec.test_procedure: Confirm if personnel involved had required training and certification for pushback procedures

children_spec.statement: Availability of necessary ground support equipment for pushback
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect if all required ground support equipment was present and functional during pushback

node.statement: Availability of necessary ground support equipment for pushback

assumptions: The TRP ground markings and blast fence represent adequate ground support equipment for pushback availability.
The presence and qualifications of the trainee and instructor imply availability of necessary equipment.
No mechanical faults were reported or observed during the incident.
defeaters: If evidence showed missing or inadequate ground support equipment or markings, or if mechanical faults were documented, the conclusion might shift.
If communication failures or coordination breakdowns were evidenced, the procedural deviation attribution would be weakened.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4, H8, and H9 directly indicate that necessary ground support equipment and markings (TRP) were available and known, and the procedural deviation was due to operator actions rather than environmental or mechanical factors. Communication was maintained (H1, H2, H3, H8), supporting procedural deviation over communication breakdown or mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of equipment unavailability or mechanical failure; reliance on operator statements and observed behavior introduces some ambiguity.

node.statement: Availability of functional communication equipment between cockpit and ground crew during pushback

assumptions: Functional communication equipment implies availability of communication between cockpit and ground crew.
Lack of warning signals despite equipment availability indicates procedural deviation rather than communication failure.
defeaters: If evidence showed communication equipment was non-functional or no communication was possible, this would favor communication breakdown.
If there was evidence of environmental or mechanical issues causing the incident, it would change the interpretation.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1 confirms functional communication equipment was available between cockpit and ground crew; H8 indicates communication signals were attempted but not effective, supporting procedural deviation rather than communication breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Potential ambiguity in effectiveness of communication despite equipment availability.

node.statement: Availability of trained personnel assigned to pushback operation

assumptions: Presence of instructor and trainee implies availability of trained personnel
No contradictory evidence about personnel availability is present
defeaters: If evidence showed lack of trained personnel or unavailability during pushback
If communication failures were documented that better explain the deviation

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4, H8, and H9 directly describe the presence and actions of trained personnel during the pushback, showing the trainee and instructor roles and their interaction, supporting availability of trained personnel for the pushback operation. The discriminator disc:R1_PUSHBACK_PROCEDURAL_DEVIATION|R2_COMMUNICATION_BREAKDOWN favors procedural deviation over communication breakdown based on stop-point and continuation behavior.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit mention of personnel availability constraints or failures; some ambiguity in communication effectiveness

children_spec.statement: Required environmental markings were missing or obscured
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect the aircraft and surrounding environment for presence and visibility of required markings; absence or obscuration would lower the probability

children_spec.statement: Environmental conditions prevented availability of markings
children_spec.test_procedure: Evaluate weather and lighting conditions at the time; conditions such as fog, darkness, or precipitation that obscure markings would raise the probability

children_spec.statement: Markings were present but not maintained or degraded to unreadable state
children_spec.test_procedure: Assess the condition and maintenance records of markings; evidence of wear, fading, or damage would increase likelihood

node.statement: Determine the resistance of mechanical/control failure data to defeaters in the context of Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 within the hist_dynamic_und_t2_interim scope.

assumptions: No explicit hardware fault codes or bench checks were reported
Procedural deviations were not evident from the evidence
defeaters: If evidence showed clear procedural errors or operator deviations causing the failure
If hardware fault codes or repeat malfunctions were absent or contradicted

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 and H8 directly indicate that the aircraft moved beyond the TRP despite the tug instructor's efforts and that communication signals were insufficient, supporting mechanical/control failure over procedural deviation.

node.statement: Required environmental markings were missing or obscured

The inability to stop at the TRP is attributable to marking visibility or adequacy rather than solely human error
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were clearly visible and unambiguous to all involved personnel
If verified fault codes or repeat malfunctions indicated a mechanical control failure instead
If crew communication or procedural deviations were the primary cause rather than marking deficiencies

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. This supports the claim of missing or obscured required environmental markings.

node.statement: Mechanical components required for control were physically present in the aircraft

assumptions: Presence of engine at idle and running APU implies mechanical components required for control were physically present
No evidence of mechanical parts being absent or non-functional prior to the incident
defeaters: If evidence showed mechanical components were missing or physically damaged prior to the event
If hardware fault codes or repeat malfunctions were documented
If communication failures were clearly documented and linked to the event

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 and H6 directly indicate the aircraft's mechanical components for control were physically present and operational (engine at idle, APU running), supporting the claim. Discriminator disc:R2_COMMUNICATION_BREAKDOWN|R4_MECHANICAL_CONTROL_FAILURE favors mechanical failure over communication breakdown due to lack of corroborated hardware faults.
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence / ambiguity
